prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect fine-structure line of [CII] at 157.74 micron on LIRGs at 4 < z < 5. At this redshift range the [CII] line is redshifted to ~ 790 - 950 micron, corresponding to the wavelength coverage of band 7. The water absorption line at 325GHz in the middle of band 7 divides the band into roughly 2 30 GHz window ideally suited for the setup of spectral scan. In this Science Goal we request the spectral scan starts from 330 GHz to 360 GHz, corresponding to 4.28 < z < 4.76.

To maximize the detectability of our spectral scan we request our imgae to be mapped in ~1" resolution. Although most of our sources are expected to appear unresolved, some highly-amplified sources which lie close to the critical lines, such as the cosmic eyelash in Swinbank et al. (2010), could be resolved into multiple clumps.

Unlike the local star-forming galaxy population, a census of [CII] luminosity has not been established at z > 4 SMGs. However, recent work on a few [CII] detections on z > 4 SMGs have indicated a [CII] to total far-infrared (FIR) luminosity ratio of 0.1-1%. All [CII] detected z > 4 SMGs have [CII] luminosity above 10^9 solar luminosity, but with various peak intensity (~ 20-100 mJy) and line width (~200-700 km/s). To be conservative, we adopt a [CII] line peak intensity of 20 mJy and a linewidth of 300 km/s, and this gives an integrated [CII] luminosity of ~2-4 times 10^9 solar luminosity at 4 < z < 5. The median observed 850 micon fluxes of our sample is 3.8, as bright as those recently dicovered bright SMGs with [CII] detection by ALMA (e.g., ALESS 61.1, ALESS 65.1 and LESS 76; De Breuck et al. 2011, Swinbank et al. 2013). We therefore adopted a similar senstivity requirement in Swinbank et al. (2013), meaning a spectral sensitivity of 4.9 mJy per 31.25 MHz channel (They binned to 62.5 MHz with 3.5mJy r.m.s.; right panel in Figure 2). This setup will allow us to obtain ~6 sigma detection on a [CII] line similar to our adoped line profile (ALESS 61.1 in Swinbank et al. 2013). This is likely a conservative assumption given that our sample sources are intrinsically fainter than bright SMGs presented in Swinbank et al. (2012). Although it is yet confirmed with SMGs, studies on the local star-forming galaxy population (Brauher et al. 2008) as well as on a few z ~ 4 [CII] emitting, star-bursting galaxies (Maiolino et al. 2009), have shown that [CII]-to-FIR luminosity ratio increases as FIR luminosity decreases, suggesting that our candidate sources would have higher 'observed' [CII] luminosity than our conservative assumption. In any case, thanks to lensing, our requested spectral sensitivity is well suited to test this assumption (left panel in Figure 2). Our spectral scan will also yield band 7 continuum with ~ 0.15 mJy r.m.s. continuum sensitivity based on the OT calculator, which will allow us to detect our sample sources to > 10 sigma.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our recent SCUBA-2 survey of 40 massive lensing clusters has uncovered more than 60 faint submillimeter faint SMGs, with 850 micron fluxes less than the blank-field confusion limit (<2mJy). With typical lensing amplifications of 2-30, this sample represents one of the largest high-redshift luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs) samples. Recent studies suggest that high-redshift LIRGs are the dominant contributors to the obscured star formation rate densities (SFRDs) at z > 4, and a substantial fraction of the faint SMGs are not detected in deep UV observations. We propose to conduct [CII] line searches on a sample of 20 Herschel red or drop-out z > 4 LIRGs cadidate. We aim to address (1) how much of the obscured star formation densities are there in z > 4 LIRGs, (2) what is the fraction of z > 4 LIRGs that can not be recovered in deep UV images and consequently what are the biases on the measurements of SFRD with UV data alone, and (3) what are the physical conditions of the interstellar medium of z > 4 LIRGs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
